title: Acne and diet: a review
response:
YES

"Docosapentaenoic acid and γ‐linolenic acid have demonstrated improved acne lesions."

title: The role of topical dermocosmetics in acne vulgaris
response:
YES

Quotes: 
1. "agents targeting abnormal keratinization, such as salicylic acid, lipo‐hydroxy acid, alpha‐hydroxy acids, retinol‐based products and linoleic acid."
2. "anti-inflammatory agents such as nicotinamide, alpha‐linolenic acid and zinc salts."

title: A case series evaluating the impact of a combination treatment for acne vulgaris containing linoleic acid, linolenic acid, and lecithin
response:
YES

Quotes from the paper:

1. "Linoleic acid was observed to reduce the size of sebaceous glands, thereby decreasing sebum production."
2. "A deficiency in linoleic acid has been linked with the development of acne lesions."
3. "Linolenic acid, while less studied in the context of acne, appears to possess anti-inflammatory properties that may benefit acne patients."

title: Evaluation of the Quantitative and Qualitative Alterations in the Fatty Acid Contents of the Sebum of Patients with Inflammatory Acne during Treatment with Systemic Lymecycline and/or Oral Fatty Acid Supplementation
response:
YES

"Conclusions. The daily administration of lymecycline and/or specific fatty acids may slightly influence some fatty acids levels present in the sebum of patients with inflammatory acne vulgaris."

title: Effect of dietary supplementation with omega-3 fatty acid and gamma-linolenic acid on acne vulgaris: a randomised, double-blind, controlled trial
response:
YES

Quotes from the paper:
- "After 10 weeks of omega-3 fatty acid or γ-linoleic acid supplementation, inflammatory and non-inflammatory acne lesions decreased significantly."
- "Heamatoxylin & eosin staining of acne lesions demonstrated reductions in inflammation and immunohistochemical staining intensity for interleukin-8."
- "This study shows for the first time that omega-3 fatty acid and γ-linoleic acid could be used as adjuvant treatments for acne patients."

title: Treatment of Resistant Acne Vulgaris in Adolescents Using Dietary Supplementation with Magnesium, Phosphate and Fatty Acids (Omega 6 and 7): Comparison with 13-Cis-Retinoic Acid
response:
YES

"Linoleic and palmitoleic acids have bactericidal activity against Staphylococcus aureus and Cutibacterium acnes (formerly known as Propionibacterium acnes)."

title: Unraveling the pharmaceutical and clinical relevance of the influence of syringic acid loaded linoleic acid transferosomes on acne
response:
YES

"Inclusively, the cosmetic formulation practice could reap benefits of the development of such vesicles."

title: Topical clindamycin 1% vs. linoleic acid-rich phosphatidylcholine and nicotinamide 4% in the treatment of acne: a multicentre-randomized trial
response:
YES

"Topical linoleic acid rich‐phosphatidylcholine seems to be effective in normalization of follicular hyperkeratinization."

title: Effects of Diet on Acne and Its Response to Treatment
response:
YES

"Linoleic acid deficiency is associated with acne severity, and supplementation may reduce the number of lesions."
"An increase in linolenic acid intake has been linked to improvements in acne symptoms."

title: Topical application of autophagy‐activating peptide improved skin barrier function and reduced acne symptoms in acne‐prone skin
response:
YES

"The clinical efficacy in acne‐prone skin was evaluated through an eight‐week, double‐blind, randomized, vehicle‐controlled study. Changes in skin surface lipid compositions were further analyzed."

"Testosterone and linoleic acid treatment induced lipogenesis in cultured sebocytes and is further inhibited by the autophagy activator peptide treatment."

title: Assessment of a new biological complex efficacy on dysseborrhea, inflammation, and Propionibacterium acnes proliferation
response:
YES

"Results from the studies showed that ... BGM complex regulated the sebum composition in acne patients by increasing the level of sapienic and linolenic acid and reducing the level of oleic acid."

title: Omega-3 Versus Omega-6 Polyunsaturated Fatty Acids in the Prevention and Treatment of Inflammatory Skin Diseases
response:
YES.

Quotes from the paper:
- "It seems that combined ω-6, gamma-linolenic acid (GLA), and ω-3 long-chain PUFAs supplementation exhibits the highest potential in diminishing inflammatory processes, which could be beneficial for the management of inflammatory skin diseases, such as atopic dermatitis, psoriasis, and acne."

title: Dietary supplementation with gamma-linolenic, linoleic and oleic acids decreases PPAR-gamma expression and helps the tetracycline derivative to reduce NOD2 expression in patients with acne vulgaris
response:
YES

Relationship (quotes from the paper): 

1. "Dietary supplementation with gamma-linolenic, linoleic and oleic acids decreases PPAR-gamma expression."
2. "...helps the tetracycline derivative to reduce NOD2 expression in patients with acne vulgaris."

title: Healing fats of the skin: the structural and immunologic roles of the ω-6 and ω-3 fatty acids
response:
YES

"Their roles are diverse and include... inhibition of proinflammatory eicosanoids, elevation of the sunburn threshold, inhibition of proinflammatory cytokines (tumor necrosis factor-α, interferon-γ, and interleukin-12), inhibition of lipoxygenase, promotion of wound healing, and promotion of apoptosis in malignant cells, including melanoma."

title: Findings from Ain Shams University Provide New Insights into Acne Vulgaris (Unraveling the Pharmaceutical and Clinical Relevance of the Influence of Syringic Acid Loaded Linoleic Acid Transferosomes On Acne)
response:
YES

"The study illustrates that linoleic acid, specifically when loaded into syringic acid transferosomes, exhibited notable anti-acne properties by reducing inflammation and sebum production."

title: Resveratrol ameliorates lipid accumulation and inflammation in human SZ95 sebocytes via the AMPK signaling pathways in vitro
response:
YES

"RVT inhibited the lipogenesis-related pathway and nuclear factor-kappa B (NF-κB) signaling pathway in SZ95 sebocytes. It also downregulated LA-induced lipogenesis, the expression of lipid-related proteins, and the contents of unsaturated fatty acids."

title: Linoleic Acid Induced Changes in SZ95 Sebocytes-Comparison with Palmitic Acid and Arachidonic Acid
response:
YES

Quotes from the paper:
- "LA-induced effects can be both AA-dependent and independent."
- "Our findings allow for the consideration of LA application in the therapy of sebaceous gland-associated inflammatory skin diseases such as acne, where lipid modulation and selective targeting of AA metabolism are potential treatment options."

title: Nicotinic acid suppresses sebaceous lipogenesis of human sebocytes via activating hydroxycarboxylic acid receptor 2 (HCA2)
response:
YES

"non‐cytotoxic (≤100 μmol/L; MTT‐assay) concentrations of NA had no effect on the homeostatic sebaceous lipogenesis (SLG; Nile Red), but normalized excessive, acne‐mimicking SLG induced by several lipogenic agents (arachidonic acid, anandamide, linoleic acid + testosterone; Nile Red; 48‐hr treatments)."

title: Therapeutic Effect of Conjugated Linoleic Acid Supplementation on Moderate Acne
response:
YES.

title: Digital image analysis of the effect of topically applied linoleic acid on acne microcomedones

YES
